ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] web-calculus presentation at HP Labs
ygData.msgSnippet: Tyler, I just looked at your slides and have some questions: You say a web service is a command interface for pushing commands. I think it more accurate to

Tyler,

I just looked at your slides and have some questions:

You say a web service is a command interface for "pushing" commands.
I think it more accurate to say it is an interface for "pushing" state.
Moreover, the lambda calculus is theoretically incompatible with state
change, requiring Monads as a separate path to describe state change --
calculations and commands being considerably different (see e.g.
<http://www.research.avayalabs.com/user/wadler/papers/monadsdeclare/monadsdeclare.ps>).

Perhaps I am not understanding Web Calculus, but, based on this
presentation, it strikes me as inconsistent with ReST, MoST, and the lambda
calculus.  Perhaps you can clarify.

-Alex-

PS I am in the bay area for the next week.  I'd love to meet up for coffee
and talk about this stuff in person if you have the time.


On Thu, 11 Sep 2003, Tyler Close wrote:

> Waterken Inc. recently presented the web-calculus to HP Labs in
> Palo Alto, California. The talk explains how the web-calculus is
> derived from existing REST theory, and highlights the advantages
> of this design. The presentation generated much positive
> discussion, especially amongst HP Lab's web services group.
>
> HP Labs provided wonderful A/V support, including a video of the
> presentation. The presentation video and the slides are available
> for download from the Waterken Inc. site. See:
>
> http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/HP2003/
>
> The presentation is really the first work that explains the
> functionality benefits that come from using the web-calculus. In
> explaining these benefits, the presentation also serves as a good
> primer on REST. I encourage everyone to download and view the
> video.
>
> Thanks to everyone at HP Labs who made the presentation possible.
>
> Tyler
>
